article.headline: Gonzaga 77, Santa Clara 69
article.story: SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- Mark Few isn't one to track personal milestones. Getting Gonzaga to win on the road for the first time all season mattered so much more. Few became the third-fastest coach to reach 200 wins and the Zags extended their winning streak against Santa Clara to 14 games, beating the Broncos 77-69 on Saturday night. "Wow, that's impressive," Zags senior Sean Mallon said. "That's pretty impressive. We didn't know it. He doesn't talk about that stuff." Few, in his eighth season at the Spokane, Wash., school, reached the mark in his 247th game. Only Clair Bee and Jerry Tarkanian got there faster; Bee reached 200 wins in 231 games at Rider and Long Island, while Tarkanian did so in 234 games as coach of Long Beach State and UNLV. Few's 50th, 150th and 200th victories have come at Santa Clara's expense. "It's really a staff milestone," said Few, who has kept the same assistants during his Gonzaga tenure. "I've felt strongly enough to stick around, because I wanted to. I'm happy and content. All that factored in." Derek Raivio had 25 points and Josh Heytvelt scored 10 of his 12 points in the second half and grabbed seven rebounds in the Zags' 26th consecutive West Coast Conference win and 30th in a row against a conference opponent including tournament play. Only a week earlier, Santa Clara coach Dick Davey became the second-winningest coach in WCC history with 113 victories. Few isn't far behind with 92 conference wins. "It means it's hard to win when you play them," Davey said of Few's feat. "They do a great job, the whole staff. Efficient I think is the right word for them in everything they do." Gonzaga (12-6, 3-0 WCC) led 67-53 with 4:37 left but Santa Clara used a 13-2 run to close within 69-66 on Scott Dougherty's 3-pointer with 37.3 seconds remaining. David Pendergraft hit two free throws at 35.3 for the Zags. Dougherty finished with 18 points to lead Santa Clara (11-6, 1-1). Raivio missed his first free-throw attempt of the game at the 8:53 mark of the first half, ending a streak of 44 straight made shots from the line -- a WCC and school record. The streak began Nov. 24 against Butler when he went 8-for-8, and the senior point guard has missed only four free throws all season. Sean Denison had 11 points and seven rebounds for the scrappy Broncos, who couldn't do enough offensively in the second half to pull this one out. Santa Clara hasn't beaten the six-time defending WCC champions since an 84-71 victory at home on Feb. 22, 2001. That ended the Zags' 14-game winning streak -- the longest in the nation at the time. Heytvelt scored Gonzaga's first six points of the second half and Raivio made back-to-back layins to end a 10-2 run that put the Bulldogs up 51-43 lead with 16:09 to play. The Broncos answered with an 8-2 spurt featuring a 3-pointer by role player Joey Kaempf at 13:00, but then went scoreless for 6:13. "I just keep looking back to a couple of stupid plays on our part," Santa Clara guard Danny Pariseau said. "They stole one from us." It was another tough loss to the Zags for a sellout crowd of more than 4,500 fans who packed the Leavey Center, where they were as raucous as ever for the nationally televised game even though the Bulldogs aren't ranked for a change. Santa Clara, which had won three of four with an emotional 76-69 victory over Bay Area rival Saint Mary's on Jan. 6, shot 40 percent and was outrebounded 35-32. The Zags knocked the Broncos out of the conference tournament in 2001 and 2004 by a combined four points. Jeremy Pargo's layin at 4:53 capped an 11-3 Gonzaga run for a 33-28 lead and the Zags held the Broncos without a field over the final 5:45 and only one basket in the last 7:15 of the half. Santa Clara made 6 of its first 8 shots but shot 33 percent the rest of the half to trail 41-39 at the break. The theme for the game was "Dick Davey argyle sweater night," in honor of Santa Clara's 15th-year coach and his signature look. Several of his assistants sported the sweaters and so did athletic director Dan Coonan.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
